articles.headline: Set Back by Recession, and Shut Out of Rebound
articles.snippet: A lower unemployment rate for older workers masks troubling trends of reduced pay and longer job searches.
articles.abstract: A lower unemployment rate for older workers masks troubling trends of reduced pay and longer job searches.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIDGEWOOD, N.J. — In September 2012, it appeared that the world was John Fugazzie’s frozen oyster. He was in charge of dairy and frozen foods for the A.&P. supermarket chain, making $125,000 a year.

articles.headline: Growth in Global Disputes Brings Big Paychecks for Law Firms
articles.snippet: Some legal heavyweights in the United States are benefiting from a growing number of clashes over complex international deals.
articles.abstract: Some legal heavyweights in the United States are benefiting from a growing number of clashes over complex international deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Debt woes, broken contracts and soured business deals may cost global investors billions in losses and create seemingly never-ending headaches for policy makers. But there is a set of specialists profiting from such geopolitical problems: arbitration lawyers.

articles.headline: Five Years After TARP, Misgivings on Bonuses
articles.snippet: Henry Paulson on bonuses paid during the 2008 financial crisis: “There was such a total lack of awareness from the firms that paid big bonuses during this extraordinary time.”
articles.abstract: Henry Paulson on bonuses paid during the 2008 financial crisis: “There was such a total lack of awareness from the firms that paid big bonuses during this extraordinary time.”
articles.lead_paragraph: “There was such a total lack of awareness from the firms that paid big bonuses during this extraordinary time.”

articles.headline: Blasts in the Night, a Smell, and a Flood of Syrian Victims
articles.snippet: The attack has brought widespread condemnation on President Bashar al-Assad’s government, and it is shaping up as an inflection point for a war that has been grinding on for more than two years.
articles.abstract: The attack has brought widespread condemnation on President Bashar al-Assad’s government, and it is shaping up as an inflection point for a war that has been grinding on for more than two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Thousands of sick and dying Syrians had flooded the hospitals in the Damascus suburbs before dawn, hours after the first rockets landed, their bodies convulsing and mouths foaming. Their vision was blurry and many could not breathe.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Mark Mazzetti and Mark Landler

articles.headline: A Finicky Thief of the Finest Silver Is Arrested Again
articles.snippet: Silver pieces were disappearing from Southern homes when a retired New Jersey detective recognized a pattern and called an Atlanta detective, leading to the arrest of a man believed to be linked to 30 years’ worth of thefts.
articles.abstract: Silver pieces were disappearing from Southern homes when a retired New Jersey detective recognized a pattern and called an Atlanta detective, leading to the arrest of a man believed to be linked to 30 years’ worth of thefts.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Even before someone carefully removed a windowpane from a secluded Buckhead home here one rainy June night and slipped away with a 1734 silver mug that had belonged to George II, it was clear to detectives that a meticulous thief with a singular obsession was stealing the great silver pieces of the Old South.
